title: 114_hr5480
content: The "Boosting Equity for the American Middle Class Act of 2016" or the "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a refundable credit for early principal payments on certain home mortgages under section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, limited to 50% of the payments and capped at $500 annually. There is a lifetime limitation of 10 years for claiming the credit, and a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income. The "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, limited to 50% of the payments and capped at $500 annually. The credit is subject to a lifetime limitation of 10 years and a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income. Qualified home mortgage indebtedness refers to acquisition indebtedness meeting specific criteria, including being the primary residence and a traditional mortgage with a term of 15-30 years and equal payments. The credit for excess home mortgage principal payments introduced by the "BEAM Act of 2016" is subject to intervals during the term of the indebtedness. Rules related to joint returns specify that no credit is allowed for married individuals filing separately, and if the credit is allowed for a joint return, it is subject to a lifetime limitation. The credit for excess home mortgage principal payments is allowed to both spouses for joint returns, subject to a lifetime limitation. Reporting of excess payments is required for tax purposes. The text discusses conforming amendments related to mortgage tax credits, specifically inserting "36C" after "36B" in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section regarding early principal payments on certain home mortgages will apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
